message: /* December 2022 */

LouisAragon: "negationist" sources? Miroshnikov's 1964 book cited here consists of lectures he gave at Harvard University in 1962, and is based on Russian archives. The 1920 Iranian government report on military casualties cited and quoted in Majd (2013) is from US State Department archives. These are not "negationist" sources.  Besides, the first paragraph did not contain a single sourced citation. The unsourced claim that millions of Iranians died in the Armenian genocide is absurd and false.

Removed the unsourced, false, and objectionable statement that "over 2 million Persian civilians died in the conflict, mostly due to the Armenian genocide by the Ottoman regime". Added Iranian government's figure on Iranian deaths caused directly by military operations by the invaders.

There was an error in the total number of famine deaths. The actual sum of "Civilian deaths due to war-related famine and disease" given in column 4 is 22,188,000 to 32,650,000. In round numbers, it is  22 to 33 million and not 19 to 28 million given in the article. Similar to many previous conflicts, deaths by famine and disease had exceeded military deaths. It also increases the estimated overall casualty figures.
Edit and correction.

TheTimesAreAchanging. Back in January 2022, I pointed out in the article's talk page that Abrahamian had made false and defamatory claims against Majd and these are reproduced in the WP article. Received no response or feedback. Given that substance of claim is also repeated in Ayatollah Khamenei's website, matter has to be dealt with and did so in the footnotes. Removed material that could be constructed as OR.  And yes, Cronin cites Majd in her famine deliberations.

Death toll. The 2 million death toll has a very shaky provenance and weak documentary basis. It should stay in the article but lack of acceptable documentation should be clearly stated. In the process, made editorial changes to and expanded the death toll section. Contemporary perceptions. Pointed out that the article contains false and slanderous accusation against one of the authors cited in the article.

In the article cited as a reference to the Iran famine, oddly, the author's name and the journal title were given in Persian despite the fact that they are given in English in the original English publication. An obvious ruse (and possible vandalism) that makes it useless to the English reader and helps conceal article content. Converted back into English, added original article PDF, and included Holocaust Encyclopedia and the original book on the WW2 Iran famine and epidemics.as references.
Causes and contributing factors: Stephanie Cronin on the primary importance of British policies.
Stephanie Cronin's recent criticism of historians for their neglect of the WWI famine and the "apocalyptic losses."
Added the two books published in London in the 1920s that are the sources for the 2 and 6 million death toll given in the text.

The previous "stable" version contains almost nothing on the suffering of the peasantry. The omission is partly rectified by inclusion of a couple of sources, including Willem Floor (2003).  A general observation: the WWI famine is an understudied topic. Maintaining a "stable" text is assuredly not the answer.
In the interest of completeness and balance, quoted from Willem Floor's 2005 review of "The Great Famine and Genocide in Persia, 1917-1919".

Restored the 2013 edition of "The Great Famine & Genocide in Iran: 1917-1919, Second Edition" which had been inexplicably removed from the list of Majd's publications, and included an additional review of the original (2003) edition of  the book.
Corrected cited book's  title and added isbn.
Name and title correction
Name correction
editorial changes
Page correction.
Changed the death toll in the info box based on pre and post-famine population figures given by 19th century and contemporary writers.
Some contemporary economists writing in the 1920s had indicated that the 1917-1919 famine toll was about 10 million.
Cited and quoted from the Holocaust Encyclopedia, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, on the impact of World War II on Iran.

Comparison of pre and post famine population figures.

Undid revision 1068655534 by [[Special:Contributions/TheTimesAreAChanging|TheTimesAreAChanging]] ([[User talk:TheTimesAreAChanging|talk]]) Neither  WW I famine nor  WWII famine is acknowledged in Bharier. O Grada dishonestly uses Bharier's famine denial as the source for his claim that the WWII famine was "probably modest". See talk pages of the two famines. All edits and revisions based on the article's two cited sources, Majd 2016 and 2021, hence no legitimate reason for deleting them.
Severity and Death Toll of World War II Iranian Famine
The death toll reported in The New York Herald of July 29, 1871, added to the article.

/* Reviews of works */ Additions. Domdeparis again repeats his false claim that Majd is "self-published", an allegation also made in 2017. Fact check: University Press of America (UPA) is a respected imprint of Rowman & Littlefield, 6th largest US publisher founded in 1949 . From the American Philosophical Association's website: "UPA has delivered high-quality research and textbooks into the hands of students and faculty in a timely manner since its founding in 1975." (www.apaonline.org)
American Philosophical Association's statement on University Press of America (UPA).

The question is why. The near violent attempt at censorship only reinforces the suspicion that these famines were genocides. Let the reader decide.

Undid revision 1056459559 by [[Special:Contributions/Domdeparis|Domdeparis]] ([[User talk:Domdeparis|talk]]) Check his Wikipedia listings. More than a dozen publications in highly respected peer reviewed journals. His UPA books have been widely reviewed. Check worldcat.org. More than 6000 holdings of Majd's books in academic libraries. It's time for those in charge of Wikipedia to intervene in this nonsense.

I agree with user Kiyan Hakim. There is only one estimate of the death toll. Period. So where is the “dispute”? No other figure is given by userTheTimesAreAChanging or anyone else. I also find the user’s inappropriate (and hostile) comments (e.g. current government of Iran) very unprofessional.
